bibl.title: Letter from Bert W. Caldwell to Henry Rose Carter, April 6, 1922

div1.p: Caldwell asks Carter about the possibility of human yellow fever “carriers”, as he has had an inexplicable case of yellow fever in his district.

April 6th, 1922.
Doctor H.R. Carter
Washington D.C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
What is your opinion as to the probability
or the possibility of the existence of yellow fever
“carriers”. By “Carriers” I mean humans who have been
infected with the disease, and who may be able to infect
mosquitos to such a degree that such infected mosquitos
may transmit the disease to susceptible humans. The
“carrier” may have had the disease, or he may exhibit the
disease by symptoms, so ill-defined as to make diagnosis
difficult. Or again the “carrier”, one might conceive,
could have a latent infection, with the leptospiri so
attentuated, as to be incapable of infecting mosquitos
until conditions were such as to greatly increase
both in numbers and in virility, and at such time be
able to infect mosquitos.

I of course appreciate that the bacteriology
of the disease runs positively against the possibility
of the existence of so-called “carriers”. But yellow
fever does not seem to be at so great a variance with
other mosquito borne disease as to definitely preclude
the “carrier” theory, I have never heard you discuss
the subject and I would like you to tell me an answering
the following questions.

PODER EJECUTIVO FEDERAL
ESTADOS-UNIDOS-MEXICANOS
MEXICO
DEPARTAMENTO
DE
SALUBRIDAD PUBLICA

Dr. M. E. Connor.
Dr. F. Castillo Najera.

1st. Is there, in your opinion, any substantial
reason for believing that yellow fever “carriers”
do not exist?

2nd. Has your experience at any time suggested that
“carriers” might be a factor in the epidemiology of
yellow fever.

3rd. Have you known of any patient having had
yellow fever a second time? If you have known
such a case, was the second attack a new infection
or was it a recrudesence of the infection, latent
from the previous attack?

I have had my interest in the possibility
of the existence of “carriers” renewed by the appear-
ance of a case of yellow fever, in an area in which it
has been endemic, and which had a formidable epidemic
in August and September of last year. The patient was
a native of the Mexican plateau, and had never been
in the “tierras calientas” but on one previous occasin
and then but for a short time. He was 28 years of age
and had come down to the sugar plantation two months
ago in January. He became ill on the 20th, of March
and exhibited definite symptoms all the way through
the disease. I saw him on the 25th, he was convalescent
on the 26th and 27th, and a telegram received to-day
advises that he has fully recovered.

This hacienda was infected in Septmber of
last year. It has a total population of 1600 people
when the cane cutting is in full blast and the mill
is running. This year the non-immune population, and

by that, I mean laborers and their families brought
to the Hacienda from the States of the Mexican plateau
number, not to exceed 150. The stegomyia index was low
about 6% house infection. The health of the community
during the past six months has been better than for
the same period in previous years. No case has been
reported since last September from that hacienda or
closer than the Cross case, last December, at Tuxtepec
some 75 miles distant.

The possibilty of any mosquito, infected during
the epidemic of last Septmber living through the
time intervening and infecting this patient could
be ruled out. I cannot say that unrecognised cases
have occurred in this hacienda during the months,
intervening since last September. That seems to be
the only explanation of the appearance of this case.
The hacienda physcian, Doctor Dupinnet, insists that
he has seen no evidences of yellow fever since last
September other than this case.

No secondary infection has occurred. The place
was promptly cleaned up, and the patient's house and
neighboring houses were fumigated in the hopes of
destroying infected mosquitoes. The patient was
promptly isolated. The non - immune population is sm
small, and at this writing 17 days after the patient
became ill, no other cases have developed.

I am sorry to trouble you with this long
letter, but aside from giving you something new to
teach me, the thought of talking over some subject

like this with you, even by correspondence, lends
so much of the charm of old times, that I cannot
resist writing.

Mrs. Caldwell and Henry, who is growing into man-
hood far too fast, are well and want to be remembered
to you and Miss Laura. We have not lost the hope of
seeing you both in Mexico, but you must come soon, for
my family are leaving in August, and the work is pro-
gressing so satisfactorily that I think it will be at
an end with the present year.
With every good wish, I remain,
